intro: Chamaefilix formosa, commonly known as the mountain rockrose, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming structure. The plant features small, pink to white flowers that bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees. Its leaves are typically gray-green, covered in a fine layer of white hairs, which help reduce water loss in arid environments. Chamaefilix formosa is often found in rocky soils and open habitats, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions.
